INTRODUCTION.</br>Yes, Mysta, yes — me much thy fables please,</br>Thy dreams of other days, and other climes:</br>For truths and kind affections with thy rhymes</br>Commix, inwoven well: — be thine to seize</br>The Poet's ground, the high aethereal way;</br>Mine the terrestrial walk:  nor me hath age</br>Yet chill'd, tho' stealing on; and so I stray</br>Into thy upper grounds, like palmer sage.</br>Here let us kindly meet, and the world see,</br>How friends may differ much, and yet may much agree.

Me too thy Spenser pleases, and his song</br>Lur'd me to Fairy-land:  there I did meet</br>King Arthur and St. George, in converse sweet,</br>Of their achievements proud, and labours long,</br>And gentlest charities, and lineage high:</br>From diff'rent lands they come, to diff'rent ways</br>They go, yet come and go as friends; so I,</br>Thy reas'nings heard, will now unfold what says</br>My secret guide; and shoulds't thou ask of me,</br>Why he near Isis taught, I will explain to thee.

It was, because he knew in early years,</br>I bath'd my limbs in Camus, classic stream;</br>And that I might unthinking lightly deem</br>Of those two kindred streams, his bright compeers:</br>For well my genius knew, in days of yore,</br>How bookmen oft, rivals in pedant pride,</br>Would over-rate each his own college lore,</br>And each the others minstrelsies deride;</br>Hence oft to Isis now my steps he leads,</br>To muse upon her banks, and tread her flowery meads.

And there he taught me still that stream to love,</br>Wherein long since my young limbs laved were;</br>For that great Spenser, Milton, Cowley, there,</br>Dryden and Gray, whilom were wont to rove,</br>And were baptiz'd, as in some wizard stream;</br>And will'd, too, I should ponder well and long,</br>That Chaucer, of old British bards supreme,</br>In Isis wash'd; but that the Prince of Song,</br>Immortal Shakespeare, Nature's fav'rite child,</br>Bath'd in no classic stream, but ranged the mountains wild.

VISIONS.</br>In that blithe season, when on every spray</br>Life lifts the fluttering wing, and warms each flower,</br>In muse-frequented, fancy-colour'd bower,</br>Sleeps prisoner, lock'd in visions deep, I lay:</br>Cherwell, fair river, flow'd the bower beside,</br>Moist'ning the bank, as wont, with kisses sweet;</br>While Isis pour'd along her silver tide,</br>Her kindred stream in kind embrace to meet:</br>Ah!  thus, I cried, as now these streams combine,</br>Might man with fellow-man in friendly union join.

The stately sun had left his mid-day throne,</br>And on the waters play'd his sloping beam;</br>Silent awhile the feather'd warblers seem,</br>And faint with heat the daisied meadows shone.</br>Soon as soft slumbers had ensnar'd my eyes,</br>I heard a voice which spoke in accent strong:</br>"Bright scenes shall rise successive:  man be wise,</br>And mark each shadowy form which glides along:"</br>All is now still; a lighter landscape shines,</br>Of Nature's gayest green, of Beauty's softest lines.

One Vision soon is past, when I behold</br>A POWER descend, that nine fair virgins led:</br>A glory beams from his ambrosial head,</br>Bright are his eyes, his sandals shine with gold;</br>Down his young form a golden vestment flows;</br>His golden harp with skill is aptly strung.</br>And now with musings deep his visage glows,</br>While all around in mute expectance hung;</br>But when the minstrel strikes the harmonic lyre,</br>What high-wrought raptures seize that sacred sister choir!

What pencil may describe those virgins fair,</br>Their mystic forms, their eyes ethereal light?</br>When poesy's and music's powers unite,</br>Who may their many-mingling charms declare?</br>These damsels now by turns responsive sing,</br>Then wake in chorus, harp, and pipe, and lute,</br>Sound the gay timbrels, shrill the cymbals ring,</br>As different sounds their different genius suit.</br>Thus Nature ever various loves to please,</br>Thus from mixt forms calls forth her wond'rous harmonies.

Their song was proud — of gods, and heroes brave;</br>Of Jove loud-thundering, and his awful queen;</br>And her that virgin rare, of sylvan mien;</br>And beauty's goddess, sprung from ocean's wave;</br>Nor less of her, the warrior, from whose eye</br>Beams wisdom, gorgon-terrors from whose breast,</br>Nor less of him, that God, the tempest high</br>Who lifts, or calms at will, its rage to rest;</br>Of all who fill the empyreal plain,</br>Or thro' the skies, earth, fire, and water, boundless reign.

Beside a beech, list'ning with his rude throng,</br>Hung Orpheus, master of the melting lyre;</br>And near old Hesiod, and the vagrant sire,</br>Blind Homer, who so rous'd th' heroic song,</br>The glory of great Greece:  others were there,</br>Bards, fam'd thro' Greece, still of illustrious names,</br>Some Roman, who those muses smiles wont share,</br>(Some now ingulph'd in time, unknown to fame)</br>Foremost of whom, Ennius, of distant age,</br>With Maro, polished bard, and with Lucretius sage.

But quickly now successive to my view,</br>Far different forms, and different scenes unfold,</br>Suns empyrean-bright, and skies of gold,</br>Hills ever green, and fields of heavenly hue;</br>And far away, two wide extended streams,</br>Sacred the names, and dear to eastern lore;</br>(More stately move not in the poet's dreams)</br>Roll their proud waves beside the silent shore,</br>And hark!  a thousand songs to Mithra rise,</br>Luxuriant as the fields, and glowing as the skies.

The rapturous notes fill every sacred bower,</br>Till now, as slumbering, clos'd the eye of day:</br>Then pour'd the nightingale his liquid lay,</br>Perch'd on a branch beside his favourite flower.</br>And near that flower his eyes are glittering bright;</br>And near that flower his notes so wildly rove,</br>As tho' his little breast with fond delight</br>Would break, for blooming ROSA was his love.</br>Thou sweetest flower, oh!  still thy stay prolong,</br>Oh!  sweetest bird, still pour that soothing, melting song.

Here gay, o'er wine, with each a dainty dame,</br>Hafez and Sadi sat; nor far away</br>Rose Cassem, far renown'd for classic lay;</br>And Abilola, bard of loftier name;</br>And he, that shepherd, who gave Israel law,</br>And he who glorious rul'd, their tuneful king;</br>And such as taught in prophets schools, and saw</br>Visions, and wak'd inspired the mystic string,</br>The first of whom, Isaiah, nor less he</br>Who moraliz'd in song, thro' the blest Araby.

Now, as just rais'd from fiery surge, behold</br>Beings, monstrous gods, by God and man accurs'd,</br>Satan, arch-fiend, and Moloch, mad with thirst</br>Of human blood, and Mammon gorg'd with gold;</br>And other forms, huge, hideous, hateful, base;</br>Gods once of Egypt, or Phoenicia's coast,</br>Or Syrias, with Belial's beastly race,</br>Mail'd with dark panoply, a dreadful host!</br>Furious as fiery storms from Etna rise,</br>Which deluge all the land, and purple all the skies.

'Gainst Heaven's high King, I saw them waging war;</br>I saw them plung'd headlong to deepest hell;</br>I saw them plotting machinations fell,</br>Plotting, tho' fall'n, in Pandaemonium far:</br>And against whom those machinations vile?</br>'Gainst man, and his long feeble progeny.</br>I saw the tempter give — with baleful smile;</br>I saw the tempted take the gift and die.</br>Ah!  splendid horrors all; but short their stay;</br>How like a thunder-storm, that growls, and dies away!

Chang'd is the scene. — Now towering forms I view,</br>With limbs of giant size, they march along;</br>Loud they pour forth the hoarse prophetic song;</br>Bold is their front; their eyes of sullen blue.</br>Louder and louder bursts their martial strain,</br>(Clash their rude shields responsive to the sound)</br>As now embattling fierce, they scour the plain,</br>Where grisly foemen groaning bite the ground.</br>"Joy to the brave" — I hear the bardie cry;</br>"Shout, shout (the day is won) the song of victory."

And now the rites begin, dark groves among,</br>Long consecrate in wood-crown'd isle most fair;</br>Tuisto and Mannus all due honours share;</br>(The Gods of nations claim the warriors song)</br>But her in hymns accordant long and loud,</br>Hertha, the all-prolific source of life,</br>Her most they celebrate in vestments proud,</br>High-thron'd in chariot bright:  hush'd is all strife;</br>And war has dropp'd his lance; for all around</br>The goddess fills the groves, and terrors rock the ground.

Now flutter forms fantastic, dimly seen,</br>Fays, Genii, Monsters, Spirits, a motley band,</br>And he, who whilom rul'd through fairy-land,</br>That merry, pranking king, and elfin queen.</br>"Oh!  stay thee, Oberon — lo!  a gentle knight</br>Implores thy aid, on val'rous deeds intent;</br>True to his love, and panting for the fight,</br>On great emprize to lands far-distant bent."</br>Oberon is stay'd; and "take that horn," he cries,</br>And "take that sacred ring and every danger flies."

And lo!  a castle rears its stupendous wall,</br>And fiery dragons guard the building round;</br>Ah!  who would dare to tread infernal ground?</br>The knight has dar'd:  no terrors may appal:</br>Though hell were in that place, he must advance:</br>Deep foams his fiery steed, and prances high,</br>Till by the terror of his flaming lance,</br>Close lock'd in death those raving monsters lie.</br>Loud sounds his horn:  wide the gates open spread;</br>And proud he enters thro', and towers his crested head.

And, oh!  what freezing scenes to view unfold!</br>How stare, with horror wild, his stony eyes!</br>What piteous howlings, what heart-rending cries!</br>Stound are his ears; his blood runs shivering cold!</br>Here deep enthrall'd lies many a lady bright,</br>Ah!  doom'd by giant curs'd to writhe in pain,</br>Or yield, vile service, to his damn'd delight,</br>Who deep-retir'd here holds his dev'lish reign:</br>But by the knight's stout arm the monster fell,</br>Has felt the stroke of death and hastens down to hell.

"Now, ladies, take heaven's ever-blessed boon,</br>Freedom is yours:  God speed you on your way:"</br>And now the knight shall hail th' all-glorious day:</br>High his desert, and he shall triumph soon:</br>A princess bright (such honours crown the brave)</br>In pride of youth awaits thy wish'd return;</br>Full many a fair, Sir Knight, 'twas thine to save;</br>Nor vainly did that breast with glory burn.</br>But lo!  the fairy scene eludes my sight,</br>Fled is the princess fair, and fled the valorous knight.

But hark!  the master of the Runic rhyme</br>Strikes the rude shell and wakes the mystic lay:</br>And see!  the KING OF MEN pursues his way.</br>To try Varthrudnis' art in things sublime.</br>Now Gothic lore is beaming on my sight;</br>Now sacred truth enchains my wond'ring mind;</br>Whence earth, and heav'n, and all those worlds of light;</br>The mighty gods and heroes of mankind;</br>Who drives morn's rising car, and evening's low;</br>Whence all the flowers that bloom, and all the herbs that grow:

And what that stream, which gods divides from earth;</br>And whose that arm, which durst with Odin war;</br>Whence Godhead's source, and Niflhil thence how far;</br>And whence that old Bergelmer owes his birth;</br>And where Valhalla, seat of noble men,</br>Who bravely fought, and durst in youth to bleed;</br>And where that nameless winter holds its reign,</br>Which must some new created world precede;</br>And where yon sun shall hide, when mighty THOR</br>Shall, midst a world in flames, extinguish ruthless WAR.

But lo!  now glimmers thro' the thicken'd air,</br>Helmets, and shields, and many a sparkling lance;</br>And see those SISTERS grim!  quick they advance!</br>Orkney for woe!  Erin for woe prepare!</br>Lo!  north and south those dragon-sisters fly!</br>Grim-visag'd terror scowls on all the plain—</br>And hark!  those ponderous groans, that lengthening cry!</br>The cry, the groan of many a warrior slain!</br>Oh!  scene of horrors, close upon my eyes!</br>Sped are those grisly dames:  and lo!  that vision flies.

Dark now the scene, and lengthening still the land!</br>'Tis Caledonia. — How her forests frown!</br>Picts, like bees swarming thick, see rushing down</br>Southward, and now in hosts embattled stand!</br>Soon Fingal's spirit stalks, while Ossian's song</br>Rouses, such power have sounds, the martial flame;</br>Here Bruce's, Baliol's, rival armies throng;</br>There pensive Wallace with his faithful Graham:</br>Now border-chiefs, and Danish now arise:</br>And dauntless, tho' in pangs, hear how great Ragnar dies.

But ruffian squadrons still embattle round,</br>And guilty conquest has distain'd the field:</br>Heralds of peace — must they to fury yield?</br>Shall unarm'd victims feel the dastard's wound?</br>Yes!  they have fall'n, the bards, fair Cambria's pride,</br>Truth's tuneful priests — with heaven they left the prayer;</br>And not unmourn'd the blameless victims died;</br>See beck'ning spirits hover in the air;</br>While brave Aneurin mourns his Hoel slain;</br>And pity droops the head at soft Llewellyn's strain.

Thus do these visionary pageants gleam;</br>Some quick retire, others as quick arise,</br>(As those bright forms to Jacob from the skies,</br>Past, and repast, gilding his midnight dream.)</br>Ah!  scenes that do but live in fiction's eye,</br>Yet can, like charms, beguile a life of woe.</br>Too true to truth, who would each day-dream fly,</br>Who, rob'd in wisdom, fancy's worlds forego?</br>Return, ye fabled forms, if ye can please,</br>Oh!  still, ye visions, rise, and wrap my soul in ease.

Now all is past; and not a being seen;</br>While silence reigns (as when in spring, a shower</br>Sheds on the meadows round, its fruitful store,</br>And leaves the grateful landscape all serene)</br>But soon — thus changeful is the life of man—</br>My genius leads me to a secret cave,</br>Form'd by proportion's nicest, truest plan,</br>And ocean rolls beside the placid wave.</br>Straight as I enter, oh!  what sweet surprise</br>Has seiz'd my raptur'd heart, and fill'd my ravish'd eyes!

There art had cull'd from nature's stores divine;</br>There plac'd in brilliant rows with studious care,</br>Whatever boasts the sea, of treasures rare;</br>Whate'er of sparkling ore conceals the mine;</br>The branching coral, red, and white, and blue,</br>The silvery pearl, the crystal bright and clear,</br>Em'ralds of green, the ruby's scarlet hue,</br>The pride of climes, and blossoms of the year;</br>All that could please and charm a gazer's eyes:</br>For here, though small the spot, did seem a paradise.

By nymphs attended, here a sylvan maid,</br>(Cities she fled, and spurn'd the chain of love;</br>Her love, to range the mountain, stream, and grove)</br>Finds rest and coolness in the quiet shade;</br>And near, an aged dame of power supreme,</br>Prolific parent she, the sov'reign high</br>Of the world's boundless realms, yet fond did seem</br>Of simplest chaplet, cull'd from meadows nigh.</br>How mild her eye! — Thus beams the morning light—</br>But all the goddess-form swells full upon my sight!

"Be thine," she said, and gaz'd upon the flowers,</br>With looks which wisdom mixt with love express'd,</br>"With many a dazzling scene thy mind to feast;</br>To follow fiction through her magic bowers;</br>To trip with Fancy in her airy dance,</br>With tiptoe revelries, and wild surprise;</br>To mark each pageant in its proud advance</br>From shadowy deeps, and visionary skies:</br>Sweet are the haunts, wherever genius roves,</br>Through fields of vision'd bliss, or academic groves.

"Sooth'd into softness by the melting song,</br>Charm'd into reverence by the mighty theme,</br>Be thine to kindle at each muse's dream,</br>To hail with reverence all the tuneful throng.</br>Theirs be the praise — nor slender be the praise—</br>To make new worlds — to burst the bounds of time—</br>Their stately monument of fame to raise—</br>And on the heart to bind the mystic rhyme—</br>Bold their design, each daring charm to seize,</br>And rouse to wonder, where they mean to please.

"Thine be the warblings of the peaceful lyre,</br>Peaceful, but not inglorious; thine to sing,</br>The morning's glittering eye — the virgin spring—</br>—The power of beauty — freedom's holy fire;</br>To guide the youthful poet on his way;</br>—To rouse the virtues — soothe the soul of pain."—</br>Enough — if Genius may but feel the lay;</br>Enough, if friendship but approve the strain:</br>And if, for life's short day-dream soon shall fly,</br>The muse may charm a pang, or check a rising sigh.</br>
